Graphical abstract The recycling of spent lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) has attracted widespread attention. Analyzing battery recycling technologies and addressing related challenges are essential for promoting sustainable energy development. The recycling and reutilization of spent lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have become an important measure to alleviate problems like resource scarcity and environmental pollution. Although some progress has been made, battery recycling technology still faces challenges in terms of efficiency, effectiveness and environmental sustainability. This review aims to systematically review and analyze the current status of spent LIB recycling, and conduct a detailed comparison and evaluation of different recycling processes. In addition, this review introduces emerging recycling techniques, including deep eutectic solvents, molten salt roasting, and direct regeneration, with the intent of enhancing recycling efficiency and diminishing environmental repercussions. Furthermore, to increase the added value of recycled materials, this review proposes the concept of upgrading recycled materials into high value-added functional materials, such as catalysts, adsorbents, and graphene. Through life cycle assessment, the paper also explores the economic and environmental impacts of current battery recycling and highlights the importance that future recycling technologies should achieve a balance between recycling efficiency, economics and environmental benefits. Finally, this review outlines the opportunities and challenges of recycling key materials for next-generation batteries, and proposes relevant policy recommendations to promote the green and sustainable development of batteries, circular economy, and ecological civilization. Keywords Spent li-ion batteries Recycle Direct regeneration High-value conversion Functional materials 1 Introduction Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have gained extensive application in electronic products, electric vehicles, and various energy storage devices, owing to their notable features, including high energy density, low self-discharge rate, and absence of memory effect [1–4] (Fig. 1 ). As the service life of electric vehicle batteries gradually expires (i.e., 5 to 8 years), the volume of spent power batteries concurrently increases. Statistical data reveals that approximately 218 GW h, equivalent to over 1.2 million tonnes of LIBs, entered the global market in 2019. Projections indicate a significant surge to exceed 2,500 GW h (over 12.7 million tonnes) by 2030 [5,6]. On the one hand, the efficient recycling of spent LIBs has become an urgent necessity to attain carbon neutrality objectives in energy storage [7,8]. On the other hand, since 2019, the prices of raw materials used for the production of LIBs cathodes, especially Li and Co, have risen sharply for many years (Fig. 2 a). In particular, the cost of cathode materials accounts for more than half of the total cost of all LIBs components (Fig. 2b) [9]. Therefore, utilizing materials recovered from spent LIBs not only reduces battery production costs but also reduces the overall energy requirements required for battery manufacturing by 48% [10]. The recycling of spent LIBs helps alleviate the depletion of strategic metal resources and is of great significance to the sustainable development of the environment and economy. Spent LIBs contain heavy metal compounds, lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6), benzene, and ester compounds, which are difficult to degrade by microorganisms. Inadequate disposal of these spent LIBs can lead to soil contamination and groundwater pollution due to the release of heavy metal ions, fluorides, and organic electrolytes, resulting in significant environmental issues [11,12]. Schematic diagrams depicting the internal structure and various shapes of LIBs are shown in Fig. 2(c–e). Structurally, LIBs consist of an outer shell and an internal cell, with the latter comprising a cathode, an anode, an electrolyte, a separator, and a current collector (Fig. 2f) [13,14]. Notably, LIBs cathode materials contain a variety of precious metals, such as LiNi x Co y Mn1 − x − y O2 cathode materials, of which cobalt (Co) accounts for 5–20 wt%, nickel (Ni) accounts for 5–12 wt%, manganese (Mn) accounts for 7–10 wt%, lithium (Li) accounts for 2–5 wt%, and its metal content exceeds that of natural ores [15,16]. If valuable metal elements in spent LIBs cannot be effectively recycled, it may be challenging to rely solely on natural mineral resources to meet future market demand [4,17]. Hence, the development of recycling technologies for spent LIBs is imperative to minimize environmental pollution and recover valuable metal resources. Currently, recycling approaches for spent LIBs predominantly encompass hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, biometallurgy, and direct regeneration techniques [18,19]. Pyrometallurgy involves subjecting the battery to direct heating within a high-temperature smelting furnace, leading to the incineration of materials such as plastics, organic matter, and graphite. The elevated temperatures facilitate metal species reduction, including Co, Ni, and Cu, generating alloys aided by reducing agents (such as aluminum foil, anode graphite, and introduced charcoal). Meanwhile, Li, Mn, and Al are entrained within the slag [20]. Although this approach enables the processing of spent LIBs at a significant scale, it falls short in recovering electrolytes, anode graphite, and valuable lithium, alongside challenges involving high energy consumption and emission of harmful gases. Hydrometallurgy requires diverse acids, bases, and chemicals for higher-purity metal acquisition, but this often results in acidic or alkaline wastewater generation, raising environmental concerns [21,22]. Biometallurgy is industrially limited due to factors such as long bacterial culture cycles and rising labor costs. The direct regeneration method involves replenishing lithium in the spent cathode through chemical and physical means and has significant advantages compared with the above methods [23,24]. Although direct regeneration of cathode materials is currently limited to the laboratory scale, it may be used on a large scale in industry in the future. Fig. 2(g−i) provides a comparative overview of the advantages and disadvantages of various recovery methods. Another promising recycling route is to convert used electrode materials into new materials or products with high-added value or specific functions, often referred to as regeneration functional materials. Such upgrading has the potential to improve product performance and quality while delivering significant environmental and economic benefits. Therefore, upgrading spent LIBs into functional materials is a recycling approach with great potential. This review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of research and development in the field of battery recycling. It encompasses the challenges and opportunities associated with battery recycling, emerging technologies and processes, and the potential applications of recycled materials. Furthermore, the review highlights critical research and policy areas requiring further exploration. The subsequent sections of the review are structured as follows. Section 2 introduces the various chemical types of spent LIBs and the pretreatment processes. In Section 3, the current state of recycling technologies, including pyrometallurgical, hydrometallurgical, biometallurgical, and direct regeneration methods, as well as an exploration of their limitations and potential applications. Additionally, a brief analysis of the degradation mechanism of spent cathode materials sets the stage for a comprehensive examination of the feasibility and development trends of direct regeneration techniques. Section 4 details the applications of regenerated functional materials, including catalysts, supercapacitors, adsorbents, graphene, etc. Section 5 discusses the feasibility of environmental and economic aspects related to the recycling of spent LIBs. Section 6 provides a systematic summary of the current recycling technology of spent LIBs. Finally, Section 7 summarizes the challenges encountered in the recycling of spent LIBs and provides insights into future directions for the field. This section places particular emphasis on crucial research areas and policies, including the development of advanced battery recycling technologies, standardization of battery design and labeling, and the integration of circular economy principles into policy frameworks. This review aims to provide a novel perspective on the field of battery recycling. It has the potential to encourage companies to carry out environmentally friendly, economical, efficient, and large-scale recycling of spent LIBs. 2 Lithium-ion batteries types and pretreatment 2.1 Typical types of spent LIBs The composition of electrode materials in LIBs is a crucial consideration, as its potential to impact battery performance and recyclability. Among these materials, the cathode material assumes a paramount role and typically consists of metal oxides, such as lithium cobalt oxide (LiCoO2, LCO), lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4, LFP), lithium manganese oxide (LiMn2O4, LMO), lithium nickel cobalt manganese oxide (LiNi x Co y Mn1 − x − y O2, NCM), and lithium nickel cobalt aluminum oxide (LiNi x Co y Al1 − x − y O2, NCA) (Fig. 3 ). LCO is the most mature cathode material for LIBs. It has the advantages of a high discharge platform, large specific capacity, excellent cycle performance, and a simple synthesis process. However, the LCO contains a large amount of relatively toxic Co and is expensive, making it difficult to ensure safety when making large-scale power batteries. The NCM material can be understood as the result of replacing a portion of the cobalt content in LCO with Ni and Mn elements. The incorporation of Ni elements can indeed produce high specific energy; however, it is accompanied by poor stability. LMO features a three-dimensional spinel structure that enhances ion flow across the electrode, thereby lowering internal resistance and enhancing current carrying capacity. Moreover, the spinel structure offers notable thermal stability, thereby significantly improving battery safety during operational use. However, it comes with the disadvantage of limited cycle and calendar life. LFP boasts a lengthy cycle life, high thermal stability, and minimal internal resistance [29]. As a result, it finds notable utilization in sectors with exacting safety standards, such as public transportation [30]. Another widely utilized ternary battery in electric vehicles is NCA, renowned for its elevated specific energy, commendable specific power, and prolonged operational longevity. However, owing to aluminum’s amphoteric nature, it is not easy to precipitate together with Ni and Co elements. Therefore, there is a threshold in the manufacturing process of NCA materials. As for anode materials, graphite and silicon typically make up the components. Some newer LIBs may use Li metal as the anode material, which can increase energy density but also has safety concerns. Additional constituents within LIBs comprise the electrolyte (mixture of lithium salts and organic solvents), a separator (a porous material that prevents electrode contact), and current collectors (typically composed of Al/Cu foil). A comprehensive understanding of the composition of LIBs is of critical importance for designing efficient and sustainable recycling methods. 2.2 Pretreatment of spent LIBs While the cathode chemistry of spent LIBs may vary, they are primarily composed of valuable metal elements such as Li, Ni, Co, Mn, Fe, Al, and Cu, all of which have good recycling potential. However, the retrieval of these metals necessitates a preliminary pretreatment of spent LIBs [31]. The pretreatment process typically involves several steps, including dismantling, crushing, and sorting the batteries [32]. During the dismantling step, batteries are systematically dismantled, segregating distinct components, including the casing, electrodes, separator, and electrolyte. Subsequently, the electrodes were subjected to crushing, rendering them into smaller fragments. Next, the crushed electrodes undergo a sorting process to separate the different metals from each other. This process typically involves a combination of physical and chemical separation methods such as sieving, magnetic separation, and flotation. Once the metals are effectively separated, further processing facilitates the recovery of these valuable materials. Additionally, pretreating spent LIBs can enhance safety. This precaution is necessary because some overcharged LIBs can generate lithium metal [33]. Without proper pretreatment during the recycling process, the exposed lithium metal may react violently with oxygen in the air, causing the battery to explode. Therefore, the pretreatment of spent LIBs is crucial for safety. Spent LIBs commonly retain a residual power ranging from 0% to 40%, posing the risk of electric shock, corrosion, and explosion [34]. A short circuit can lead to swift battery discharge, triggering thermal runaway and generating hazardous gases, such as HF, that can potentially culminate in a battery explosion. Thus, a crucial initial step involves passivating the spent LIBs to eliminate residual energy and waste lithium, effectively curbing the risk of short circuits and spontaneous combustion [35,36]. Common discharge methods for spent LIBs include the physical short circuit method, cryogenic method, and conductive salt solution immersion method. The physical short circuit method was to connect the two ends of the spent LIBs to a resistor and consume the remaining power by releasing heat. This approach was prevalent for smaller batteries, offering relatively fast discharge; however, it may lead to rapid heating within the battery cell over a short period, potentially causing explosions. Generally, the easiest way to take is to perforate the spent LIBs with metal to make it a short circuit. Moreover, conductive powders, such as copper and graphite, find application in inducing battery short circuits [37]. The cryogenic method entails reducing the temperature of all flammable components within the battery below their respective flash points, effectively deactivating the battery without igniting it. Operating at low temperatures prevents the battery from catching fire. By utilizing liquid nitrogen, a subzero environment at −198 °C can be achieved, enabling the treatment of high-capacity batteries and facilitating the simultaneous discharge of numerous spent LIBs. The conductive salt solution immersion method is to soak the spent LIBs in a conductive salt solution for some time to make it short-circuit internally and deeply release the remaining charge. This technique enhances safety, as the salt solution absorbs the heat generated during the discharge process [38]. Prominent salt solutions for this method include NaCl, FeSO4, Na2SO4, and ZnSO4. Experiments conducted by Ojanen et al. [39] identified NaCl as the most effective discharge salt solution; a 20 wt% NaCl solution achieves complete discharge of spent LIBs within 4.4 h. However, the presence of Cl− hastens battery casing corrosion and promotes electrolyte leakage, making it suboptimal as a discharge solution. In summary, the physical short-circuit method induces a rapid temperature increase in spent LIBs, rendering it impractical for large-scale industrial applications. While the cryogenic method can safely discharge a considerable quantity of spent LIBs concurrently, its costliness, primarily attributable to the expense of liquid nitrogen, renders it economically unviable. In contrast, the conductive salt solution immersion method emerges as a secure and cost-effective mode of discharge. Remarkably, the search for milder salt solutions that can discharge quickly remains a compelling focus of research. Mechanical methods [40] are commonly used to pretreat battery casings to concentrate the metal fraction before using pyrometallurgical processes. The mechanical separation of the battery requires processes such as crushing, sieving, magnetic separation, fine crushing, and classification [41] (Fig. 4 ). To enrich metal compounds and remove spent LIBs casings, Bertuol et al. [42] used mechanical separation methods to separate about 17.2 wt% of Cu/Al current collector, 15.8 wt% of Al (external casing), 42.7 wt% of a mixture of LCO and graphite, 6.1 wt% of polymer, and 2.3 wt% of a renewable mixture from spent LIBs. Mechanical separation is widely used by enterprises due to its high separation efficiency. However, due to the interpenetration of various LIBs components, such as the tight bond between the active material and the current collector, formed by the PVDF binder, achieving complete separation through mechanical means remains challenging. Fig. 5 provides an overview of the recovery of materials from spent batteries by physical separation at companies including Recupyl (France), Duesenfeld (Germany), Akkuser (Finland), and Retriev (US/Canada). Table S1 summarizes the recycling processes adopted by major battery recycling companies around the world in recent years. Major LIBs recycling companies in Europe and the United States have gradually transformed from pyrometallurgy to a combined process of mechanical treatment and hydrometallurgy. However, Asian countries such as China, Singapore, and South Korea mainly use hydrometallurgical processes to recycle spent LIBs. It is expected that hydrometallurgical processes will remain dominant for a long time to come. The researchers explored a variety of methods to separate active materials from spent electrodes, as shown in Table 1 . Alkali leaching and organic solvent dissolution have become the main methods for separating active materials in the laboratory. Alkaline solutions were very effective at dissolving current collectors (Al foil). Although this method was characterized by high separation efficiency, it results in a high Al3+ concentration in the solution and therefore requires a complex impurity removal process [43]. Based on the principle of ‘like dissolves like’, organic solvents, such as dimethylformamide (DMF), N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [22,44], can effectively dissolve the binder PVDF, enabling subsequent separation of active materials. However, organic solvents entail elevated costs, pose toxicity risks, and engender environmental and human health concerns. The pyrolysis approach involves the thermal separation of constituents by subjecting the binder to temperatures sufficient for melting or decomposition. This method generally keeps the temperature above 400 °C for some time, removes the binder PVDF, and separates the positive electrode material from the Al foil. To overcome the hazards of HF during high temperatures and pyrolysis, Wang et al. [45] introduced calcium oxide (CaO) as an additive. This innovation notably lowered the PVDF decomposition temperature. Notably, the active material separation rate soared to 97.1 wt% at a mere 300 °C, and the HF released from PVDF decomposition could be in-situ absorbed by CaO. This study proposes a practical way to solve HF emissions during pyrolysis. Furthermore, this improved pyrolysis process is expected to be applied in large-scale production in enterprises. 3 Recycling techniques spent LIBs 3.1 Pyrometallurgy Several common recycling technologies for spent LIBs are pyrometallurgy, hydrometallurgy, biometallurgy. Pyrometallurgy involves the use of high temperatures to extract and purify metals from spent LIBs. It is a complex process that involves several steps, including roasting, smelting, and refining. During roasting, the electrode material undergoes heating in the presence of air to eliminate volatile components and other impurities [54]. In the smelting process, the roasted electrode material is melted with a reducing agent, which removes the remaining impurities and leaves the pure metal behind (Fig. 6 ). Finally, the refining process involves further purification of the metal through various techniques, such as electrolysis or distillation. Pyrometallurgy can handle large volumes of spent LIBs, produce high-quality metal products, and recover metals that are difficult to extract using other techniques [55]. This method often offers quicker and more cost-effective results compared to alternative techniques, owing to its streamlined extraction and purification processes. However, pyrometallurgy also has many disadvantages, for instance, the inability to recycle the electrolyte, and lithium is easily lost in the slag. Additionally, pyrometallurgy releases pollutants, such as sulfur dioxide and other gases, into the environment during the smelting process [56]. Scholars are working to develop new technologies for capturing and treating pollutants that are released during the pyrometallurgical processes. 3.1.1 Roasting Carbonthermal reduction roasting is one of the most important methods for recovering cathode materials in pyrometallurgy. During carbothermal reduction roasting, the cathode material is heated together with a reducing agent such as carbon or coke, and the alloy/metal oxide mixture is left for further refining [57]. This technique efficaciously affects the reduction of high-valence transition metal oxides into low-valence states, obviating the requirement for introducing supplemental reducing agents during ensuing leaching processes. Notably, carbothermal reduction promotes the destruction of oxygen octahedra in the crystal structure of metal oxides, which makes it easier for Li and Co to leach [58]. Li et al. [59] roasted a mixture of LCO and graphite at 1000 °C for 30 min under a nitrogen atmosphere. The results showed that the roasted products are composed of graphite, Co, Li2CO3, 98.93% of Li, 95.72% of Co, and 91.05% of graphite are recovered by magnetic separation. Recently, the microwave-assisted carbothermal reduction has received great attention in the study of spent LIBs [60]. The traditional calcination processes require heat transfer, leading to relatively extended heating durations and unwarranted thermal loss. Graphite in the anode of LIBs is a naturally preferred wave-absorbing material, which allows it to be directly heated by microwave energy, greatly improving the metal recovery efficiency. Lithium carbonate (Li2CO3) is inevitably produced during carbothermal reduction roasting, however, the solubility of Li2CO3 is very low, so this process will lead to a decrease in the leaching rate of Li elements. Salt-assisted reduction roasting produces salts that are readily soluble in water, which can avoid the above problems and reduce acid consumption. Salts with low melting points, high solubility, and high volatility have attracted the interest of researchers [61]. The key to salt-assisted roasting is the conversion of transition metal oxides into soluble metal salts [62]. Salt-assisted roasting is mainly divided into chlorination, sulfation, and nitrification roasting. Notably, sulfation roasting has been proven as more ecologically benign and environmentally friendly compared to chlorination and nitrification roasting methods. Employing a vulcanizing agent during mixed roasting of the cathode material prompts the transformation of metal oxides into low-valence sulfates. Furthermore, the layered structure of the cathode material is unstable at high temperatures, and the released Li+ will combine with SO4 2− to form Li2SO4. The generation of SO x can be averted by meticulously regulating the quantity of vulcanizing agent added during the vulcanization roasting process, thus circumventing secondary pollution concerns [63–65]. By adjusting the temperature, pressure, gas, and types of roasting additives, the recovery efficiency of metal elements can be improved, and the roasting process can be made more environmentally friendly. Notably, salt-assisted roasting induces a substantial reduction in the calcination temperature compared to conventional pyrometallurgy. Through the conversion of refractory metal oxides into water-soluble salt solutions, this approach expeditiously dismantles the cathode powder structure at lower temperatures, thereby heightening the retrieval rate of valuable metals. 3.1.2 Smelting During the smelting process, the electrode material is heated above the melting point and the metal oxides are reduced in the liquid phase [55]. The process eliminates the need for pretreatment and allows the cells and modules to be smelted directly in the smelter [28]. During the smelting process, the electrolyte is heated at a low temperature to evaporate. At high temperatures, however, the electrode material is melted. Carbon and aluminum function as reducing agents, and the introduction of suitable fluxes facilitates metal melting while decreasing the melting point. One advantage of smelting is its ability to recover a wide range of spent LIBs with different chemical compositions. 3.2 Hydrometallurgy Unlike pyrometallurgy, which involves the use of high-temperature processes such as smelting, hydrometallurgy relies on low-temperature processes such as leaching, solvent extraction, precipitation, and electrowinning. Hydrometallurgy is a versatile and flexible technology that can be applied to a wide range of metal ores, as well as to the recovery of secondary sources such as spent LIBs [66,67]. The process typically involves the following steps, leaching the metal from the ore or concentrate using an acid or alkali, separating the metal from the leach solution using solvent extraction or precipitation, and electrowinning the metal from the purified solution. The employment of hydrometallurgical processes confers manifold advantages over conventional pyrometallurgy. Particularly, hydrometallurgy circumvents the requirement for elevated temperatures, leading to diminished energy consumption and curtailed greenhouse gas emissions [11]. Furthermore, hydrometallurgical methodologies offer heightened selectivity and purity for the reclaimed metals, thereby curbing waste generation and minimizing environmental impact. 3.2.1 Inorganic acid Acid leaching is considered to be one of the most effective and widespread methods for extracting valuable metals from spent LIBs [68–70]. Commonly employed inorganic acids in hydrometallurgical processes include HCl, H2SO4, HNO3, and H3PO4. Table 2 summarizes work involving acid leaching utilizing inorganic acids as leaching agents. While inorganic strong acids demonstrate the capacity to dissolve nearly all metal ions, their utilization can give rise to ecologically detrimental waste gases (e.g., Cl2, NO x , SO x , etc.) during application [71]. Transition metals generally exist in cathode materials in high valence states (such as Co3+ and Mn4+), and the addition of reducing agents such as hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), sodium bisulfite (NaHSO3), and glucose can improve the leaching efficiency [72]. These reducing agents expedite the dissolution of transition metal oxides in acidic solutions by diminishing the valence of transition metals. In a recent study, Chu et al. [73] used H2SO4 as the leaching agent, and under the conditions of the H2SO4 concentration of 2.5 mol L−1, the reaction temperature of 90 °C, and the reaction time of 2.5 h, the leaching efficiencies of Ni, Co, Mn, and Li all reached more than 99%. Barik et al. [74] used HCl as leaching agents and achieved leaching efficiencies above 99% for Co, Mn, and Li at 20% (weight/volume = w/v), HCl of 1.75 mol L−1 and a temperature of 50 °C for 2 h of reaction. At 30 °C and a pH of 1.5, Mn can be selectively separated from the leachate using sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) solution, while Li, Cu, Al, and Ni remain in the leachate. Analytical results demonstrated total recoveries of 90% for Co and 95% for Mn, respectively, while the leaching residue graphite can be effectively recycled. To avoid significant acid wastage, Chen et al. [75] used H2SO4 as a leaching agent and L-ascorbic (C6H8O6) acid as a leaching and reducing agent to recover valuable metals from spent LIBs. The leaching rates of Li, Ni, Co, and Mn reached 99.69%, 99.56%, 99.60%, and 99.87%, respectively, at a concentration of 1.5 mol L−1 for H2SO4, 0.25 mol L−1 for C6H8O6, a stirring speed of 300 r min−1, a liquid-to-solid ratio of 15 mL g−1, a temperature of 333 K and a time of 60 min. Generally, the leaching process of metals follows the shrinking-core model, according to which the leaching process is divided into five steps by Li et al. [76]. The initial stage entails the diffusion of leaching-agent molecules to the liquid–liquid interface, followed by the subsequent diffusion of these molecules through the diffusion layer to the surface of the unreacted core. In the third phase, metal dissolution transpires as leaching-agent molecules interact with the solid core at the solid–liquid interface, resulting in the metal entering the solution as ions. Subsequently, in the fourth step, metal ions diffuse through the diffusion layer toward the liquid–liquid interface. Finally, the dissolved metal ions diffuse into the solution to achieve leaching (Fig. 7 ). Inorganic acids are capable of leaching a substantial proportion of valuable metals from spent LIBs. The leaching process is relatively simple, making it a cost-effective and efficient method for recovering metals from spent LIBs. However, since inorganic acid leaching is not selective, it dissolves multiple metals at the same time, which may make the separation of metals more difficult, and the recovered metals may be of lower quality. Furthermore, this process can induce equipment corrosion during the leaching procedure, consequently escalating maintenance expenditures and compromising overall process efficiency. 3.2.2 Organic acid Although inorganic acids have demonstrated excellent performance in battery recycling, their utilization leads to acid-containing waste streams, emitting harmful substances (e.g., SO2, SO3, NO x ), and generating toxic residues that unavoidably inflict environmental damage [4]. On the other hand, organic acids mainly derived from microorganisms have negligible impact on the environment [95]. The strength of organic acids is often determined by the relative stability of the acid’s conjugate base and other groups, including –OH, –OS, enol, alcohol, thiol, and phenol groups [96]. Although organic acids are less acidic than inorganic acids, most organic acids are thermally stable and capable of forming strong chelates [97]. Table 3 reports some studies on the recovery of metal elements from spent LIBs using organic acids as leaching agents. In essence, organic acids can serve as leaching agents in the metal dissolution process and assume a significant role as complexing agents [98]. During the leaching process, hydrogen ions attack the metal and dissolve it into a solution. In the complexation process, the organic acid complexes with the metal to form a stable metal ion [99]. The strength of the bond between the hydrogen and oxygen within the hydroxyl group of the carboxylic acid significantly influences the rate of complexation. Moreover, organic acids exhibiting a greater number of hydroxyl groups manifest a more pronounced complexing effect. Notably, certain organic acids also exhibit reducing properties, exemplified by ascorbic acid. This characteristic is particularly useful in dissolving metal oxides presenting high-valence states. For instance, ascorbic acid functions as a reducing agent, enabling the conversion of insoluble Co (III) compounds into soluble Co (II), thereby facilitating cobalt extraction [100]. Citric acid is an excellent selective metal dissolving acid. Musariri et al. [101] used citric acid together with the reducing agent H2O2 to leach metal elements in spent LIBs. The results showed that the leaching of Co and Ni is significantly improved, but the dissolution of Mn and Fe is slowed down. Additionally, 96% of Li, 99% of Ni, and 98% of Co can be recovered using 1.5 mol L−1 citric acid and 2 vol% H2O2 at 95 °C for 30 min. In a separate investigation, Li et al. [102] investigated the recovery of Li and Co from LIBs with succinic acid as leaching agent and H2O2 as reducing agent. The results revealed that when the concentration of succinic acid is 1.5 mol L−1, H2O2 is 4 vol%, the solid–liquid ratio is 15 g L−1, the temperature is 70 °C, and the time is 40 min, the leaching rates of Li and Co are 94.65% and 99.83%, respectively. Theoretically, two kinds of leaching products containing Co (II) may be formed, namely C4H4O4Co and C8H10O8Co, with the leaching mechanism illustrated in Fig. 8 (a). Malic acid can biodegrade under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions, facilitating the management of leaching waste when employed as a leaching agent. Demarco et al. [103] employed 2 mol L−1 DL-Malic acid as a leaching agent, at a solid-to-liquid ratio of 1:20 (m/v), a temperature of 95 °C, and a time of 60 min, the leaching rate of Co, Li, and Mn is more than 90%. The utilization of DL-Malic acid for metal recovery from spent LIBs circumvents detrimental environmental impacts. Distinguished as a unique organic acid, oxalic acid not only exhibits selective leaching capabilities but also demonstrates acidic and reducing properties, further underscored by its pronounced variability in solubility [104]. While lithium oxalate displays solubility in acidic solutions, transition metal oxalates, in contrast, are insoluble and typically recuperated as precipitates. In this context, Sun et al. [105] employed oxalic acid both as the leaching agent and precipitating agent for the selective leaching of LCO. Under optimized conditions, more than 98% of Co was recovered by precipitation in the form of CoC2O4·2H2O. The attributes of organic acids, encompassing acidity, chelation, reduction capabilities, selective leaching propensity, and environmental compatibility, position them with significant potential for future applications in the domain of secondary resource recovery. 3.2.3 Ammonia leaching Ammonia leaching exhibits significant selectivity for specific metals, particularly cobalt and nickel, which are commonly found in LIBs. As a result, the process can selectively extract these valuable metals, leaving other materials behind. Despite Ni, Co, and Mn sharing similar chemical properties as transition metals, Ni and Co exhibit higher susceptibility to dissolution by ammonia reagents compared to Mn. This phenomenon can be attributed to the chelating properties of ammonia. Particularly, the [M(NH3)n]2+ (M = Ni2+, Co2+) complexes formed by Co and Ni in the presence of ammonia exhibit solubility under alkaline conditions, whereas the ligands of Mn2+ with ammonia precipitate as carbonates or oxides [120] (Fig. 8b). In another study, Wu et al. [121] orchestrated a system encompassing ammonia, ammonium sulfite, and ammonium bicarbonate to selectively leach Co, Ni, and Li from the composite electrode powder of spent NCM batteries. The leaching kinetics of valuable metals in an ammonia solution are primarily dependent on ammonium sulfite. Within this ternary leaching system, ammonium bicarbonate functions as a pH buffer, effectively stabilizing pH fluctuations throughout the leaching process. The creation of soluble ammonia-complex ions under favorable conditions enhances the leaching efficiency of Li, Ni, and Co. In a system characterized by a temperature of 60 °C, a solid-to-liquid ratio of 20 g L−1, an ammonia concentration of 1.5 mol L−1, an ammonium sulfite concentration of 1 mol L−1, and an ammonium bicarbonate concentration of 1 mol L−1, with a leaching time of 180 min, Ni and Cu are almost completely leached, and the leaching efficiencies of Li and Co are 60.53% and 80.99%, respectively. Zheng et al. [122] used ammonia and ammonium sulfate as leaching agents, and sodium sulfite as a reducing agent to leach Ni, Co, and Li from spent cathode materials. Under the temperature condition of 353 K, in the system of 4 mol L−1 of NH3, the solid–liquid ratio of 10 g L−1, 1.5 mol L−1 of (NH4)2SO4, and 0.5 mol L−1 of Na2SO3, leaching efficiencies of 94.8% for Ni, 96.7% for Li, 88.4% for Co, and 6.34% for Mn are achieved. Compared to alternative hydrometallurgical methods, ammonia leaching exhibits reduced environmental impact due to ammonia’s non-toxic and abundant nature as a leaching agent. Furthermore, it generates less toxic waste in contrast to traditional smelting techniques. Significantly, ammonia leaching holds promise for closed-loop recovery, as the ammonia in the used leachant can be recovered and reused via distillation [123]. However, ammonia leaching presents a complex process demanding precise control of variables like temperature, pressure, and pH. This makes it more difficult to optimize the process and achieve consistent results. Notably, ammonia leaching might not be universally applicable to all battery types and may be effective only with specific cathode materials, thus constraining its applicability to certain battery categories. 3.2.4 Other methods With the continuous efforts of researchers, many new methods that can improve the metal leaching rate have been developed, such as advanced oxidation-assisted method, ultrasonic assisted method, microwave-assisted method, supercritical fluid, deep eutectic solvent, molten salt, mechanochemical assisted method, electrochemically assisted method. Mechanochemical methods apply mechanical energy to condensed matter such as solids and liquids by generating mechanical forces such as shearing, friction, impact, and extrusion, inducing changes in their structure and physicochemical properties, and inducing chemical reactions [124,125]. The mechanical force causes the particles to collide with each other and with the grinding media, resulting in physical and chemical changes within the particles. The mechanochemical process can selectively extract metals from the particles by selectively inducing chemical reactions, such as leaching or solid-state reduction. Illustratively, Wang et al. [126] mixed LCO with Fe powder and NaCl after ball milling, the Li in LCO was successfully converted into water-soluble LiCl, and the residue produced by ball milling could be calcined to obtain cobalt ferrite magnetic functional materials. In this work, no acidic reagents were used, no waste liquid was generated, and the Li was recovered while converting the Co into a functional material. The mechanochemical technique exerts a pronounced influence on enhancing metal leaching rates, with rates increasing alongside rotational speed and ball-to-material ratio augmentation. This phenomenon arises due to material particle size reduction post-mechanochemical reaction, significant damage to surface morphology and crystal structure, and a consequent increase in entropy [127]. The mechanochemical method offers several advantages over traditional hydrometallurgical methods, including lower energy consumption, simpler equipment, and the ability to process a wide range of feedstocks. Additionally, the mechanochemical method can produce high-purity metal powders, making it attractive for the production of battery-grade metals. In a recent investigation, Nshizirungu et al. [128] achieved remarkable leaching efficiencies of 98.71% for Li and 97.69% for Co under optimized conditions. This success was accomplished through the utilization of waste-chlorinated polyvinyl chloride (CPVC) as the raw material, employing the subcritical hydrothermal method. Notably, metal leaching is more efficient under hydrothermal subcritical conditions and minimizes the use of large amounts of corrosive reagents. Deep eutectic solvents (DES) are composed of two or more hydrogen bond donors (HBD, such as alcohols or carboxylic acids) and hydrogen bond acceptors (HBA, usually quaternary ammonium salts) through intermolecular hydrogen bond association melting [129]. In recent years, DES has been widely used in the field of spent LIBs recycling due to its high metal extraction rate, low toxicity, safety, and biodegradability [20]. Some typical DES are used to leach valuable metals from spent LIBs (Table 5). Schiavi et al. [130] reported a method to selectively recover cobalt from hybrid lithium-ion battery electrode materials using DES (synthesized from choline chloride and ethylene glycol). To better evaluate the leaching effect of DES on metal elements, industrial-scale physically pretreated electrode powder was used. The electrode powder contains a variety of cathode materials, as well as impurities such as aluminum, copper, and iron. The research results show that compared with impurity elements (Fe, Cu), the solubility of Co, Ni, and Mn in DES has a different dependence on temperature. Based on this principle, by strictly controlling the leaching temperature and time, Cu, Co, and Ni can be selectively extracted. Specifically, at a leaching temperature of 90 °C, individual leaching of copper can be achieved. When the temperature of DES is increased to 160 °C, the leaching rate of cobalt reaches 90% and that of nickel is only 10%. By optimizing the solvent extraction process, cobalt can be recovered as cobalt oxalate and regenerated into lithium cobaltate cathode material. In addition, the residual DES solution can be reused for leaching metal elements, and its leaching effect is equivalent to that of fresh DES. In addition, the leaching effect of DES can be significantly enhanced by using acidic hydrogen bond donors (such as citric acid, acetic acid, malic acid, etc.). For example, Chang et al. [131] synthesized DES using oxalic acid and choline chloride, a solvent that recovered 99.1% Ni, 95.1% Co, and 95.3% Mn from spent NCM811 cathodes under optimized conditions of 120 °C and a mass ratio of 1/20 for the active materials to HBD. DES can selectively leach valuable metals, which can avoid subsequent complex element separation. Additionally, the recovered DES solution still exhibited excellent leaching efficiency in the subsequent leaching process, which makes DES promising for practical application in the recovery of spent LIBs. 3.3 Biometallurgy Biometallurgy, a branch of hydrometallurgy, harnesses microorganisms to extract metals from ores, concentrates, and waste materials [132]. The mechanism of metal recovery through biometallurgy involves the use of microorganisms, such as bacteria, fungi, and archaea, to dissolve metal oxide, and carbonates [133]. Among the most frequently employed microorganisms are acidophilic bacteria, like Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans and Acidithiobacillus thiooxidans, which can oxidize ferrous and sulfur compounds, yielding sulfuric acid. Fungi, archaea, and algae also feature among the microorganisms applied in biometallurgy. These microorganisms employ diverse metabolic pathways to liberate metals from mineral structures, enabling their solubilization into the aqueous phase. Subsequently, conventional hydrometallurgical techniques are employed to extract metals from the solution. Additionally, certain microorganisms and bacteria yield substances with redox properties during their activity, which are also employed for the leaching and recovery of valuable metals (Fig. 9 ). Table 4 summarizes some of the biometallurgical studies conducted by researchers. Bahaloo et al. [134] used the improved Aspergillus niger to leach valuable metals. After adapting to heavy metals, Aspergillus niger would produce different organic acids. The leaching process of metals in spent LIBs mainly utilizes gluconic acid produced by Aspergillus niger. These biological acids (citric, malic, oxalic, and gluconic) act as effective leaching and chelating agents. At a pulp density of 1% (w/v), the modified Aspergillus niger successfully leached 100% Li, 94% Cu, 72% Mn, 62% Al, 45% Ni, and 38% Co from spent LIBs. In a different approach, Xin et al. [135] used the sulfur-thiobacterium thiooxidans system to leach valuable metals and showed that the leaching of Li was most affected by H2SO4 produced by organisms, with a maximum leaching rate of 99.4% of Li in this system. Since the leaching of Ni, Co, and Mn is the joint action of Fe2+ reduction and acid dissolution, the leaching rate of Ni, Co, and Mn is the highest in the mixed energy substrate (LFP, LMO, and NCM)-mixed bacteria system. The average leaching rates of the four metals in the ternary materials are all over 95%, among which the leaching rates of Co and Ni are 96.1% and 97.2%, respectively. Bioleaching has gained substantial attention due to its merits of reduced acid consumption, low treatment costs, high leaching efficiency, safety, and environmental compatibility. Unlike chemical leaching agents, microorganisms are intrinsic to nature and pose no harm to the environment [136]. Additionally, biometallurgical processes produce fewer pollutants and consume less energy than traditional methods, making them more sustainable and cost-effective. Nonetheless, the bioleaching process for LIBs necessitates the determination of optimal leaching conditions and is hampered by sluggish kinetics, limiting its widespread industrial adoption [124]. The field of biometallurgy is rapidly advancing, and there is a growing interest in exploring its potential for the recovery of metals from various sources. Furthermore, biometallurgy can synergize with other technologies, such as hydrometallurgy, to amplify the efficiency and selectivity of metal retrieval. 3.4 Purification of leaching solutions The leachate inevitably contains impurity elements (Al3+, Cu2+, Fe3+/Fe2+, etc), which have a great impact on the purity and performance of the product, so the leachate needs to be purified and separated. The methods used in the separation and purification process generally include extraction, precipitation, and electrochemical methods. 3.4.1 Extraction Solution extraction mainly relies on the different solubility of metals or metal compounds in aqueous and organic phases [34]. Solvent extraction aims to segregate the leached metal elements while eliminating impurity ions. Extraction separation needs choosing a suitable extractant and using the extractant to form complexes of various ions, and then enter the extract. Table 6 summarizes the separation of metals from leachate by different organic extractants, and the suitable pH ranges of different extractants are shown in Fig. 10 . Commonly used extractants are bis(2,4,4-trimethyl-pentyl) phosphinic acid (Cyanex 272), di-(2-ethylhexyl) phosphoric acid (D2EHPA), 2-ethylhexyl phosphonic acid mono-2-ethylhexyl ester (PC-88A), diethylhexyl phosphoric acid (DEHPA), trioctylamine (TOA), etc. Yang et al. [156] achieved co-extraction of Mn and Co using H2SO4 and H2O2 system leaching followed by adjustment of pH = 5 and a volume fraction of PC88A of 30% compared to the volume ratio of oil phase/aqueous phase (O:A) = 2:1, which extracted 98% of Mn and over 90% of Co. The separation of Ni and Li was carried out by 30 vol% Versatic 10 extractant at pH = 4, O/A ratio of 1/3, and almost 100% of Ni was extracted. This method can effectively recover valuable metals from spent cathode materials, but impurities such as Al and Fe can adversely affect the extraction process and product purity. Consequently, additional investigations concerning the influence of impurities on the solvent extraction process are imperative. The phosphorus ionic liquid Cyphos IL 102 has been explored as a novel extractant for the selective extraction of cobalt from spent LIBs. Diman et al. [157] used Cyphos IL 102 diluted with toluene as an innovative extractant for cobalt recovery to extract Co from chloride media. Cobalt forms tetrahedral anionic chloride complexes at high chloride concentrations, which are extracted into the organic phase as [P+ 66614]2[CoCl4 2−]. Cobalt extraction exhibits endothermic (+ΔH) and spontaneous (−ΔG) characteristics. Cobalt can be almost completely extracted with 100% purity in a single stage with an O/A ratio of 1/1 using 0.05 mol L−1 HCl. Cobalt can be recovered directly from the supported organic phase in the form of Co3O4. Additionally, Co, Mn, and Li recovered as oxides/carbonates with recoveries of 98.6%, 99.9%, and 99.6%, respectively. After ten extraction-stripping cycles showed that the performance of the extractant did not decrease significantly, so it can be considered that the extractant has good recoverability. The extraction system in which multiple extractants act synergistically has also been used, which not only improves the extraction efficiency but also enhances the metal selectivity [98,99]. For example, Wang et al. [158] demonstrated that the selectivity and extraction performance of the mixed extraction system of Cyanex272 and PC-88A was due to the single Cyanex272, and the mixed system had obvious synergistic effects on Co, Mn, and Cu. Although the purity of the metal elements obtained by extraction is high, there are disadvantages such as complicated operation processes and expensive extraction agents. Therefore, future development of environmentally friendly extraction agents that are cost-effective, efficient, and capable of being recycled multiple times is necessary. 3.4.2 Precipitation The chemical precipitation method offers a simple and efficient approach to metal recovery from leachate. High-purity metal products can be obtained at low cost through the use of suitable chemical precipitants such as sodium hydroxide, ammonium oxalate, sodium carbonate, and oxalic acid [167]. The chemical precipitation method is based on the different solubility of metal chemicals under different pH conditions and the method of separating valuable metals one by one by precipitation [168] (Fig. 11 a). Chen et al. [80] used a dimethylglyoxime reagent to precipitate Ni at an equilibrium pH of 5 and C4H8N2O2 of 0.5 mol L−1 at room temperature to recover about 98.7% of Ni. Additionally, Co and Li were precipitated with 0.5 mol L−1 ammonium oxalate solution [(NH4)2C2O4] and hot saturated sodium carbonate solution (Na2CO3, 95 °C). Add a slightly excessive amount of ammonium oxalate (1.1 times the stoichiometric amount) to the oxalate, the reaction time is 30 min, the stirring speed is 300 r min−1, and the recoveries of Co and Li are 97.89% and 99.18%, respectively. This process effectively facilitates the recovery of all metals present in the leach solution, not just Co and Li. Moreover, the various reagents used all show high selectivity to metal recovery, and the obtained products have high purity. Yang et al. [156] used H2SO4 and H2O2 solution system to leach valuable metals of spent LIBs, then separated Co and Mn by selective precipitation method. Firstly, 0.076 mol L−1 KMnO4 was added to the leaching solution, the pH was adjusted to 0.5, and then precipitated at 80 °C for 60 min, and more than 90% of Mn could be recovered. The advantage of the precipitation separation method is that it is easy to operate, but the disadvantage is that other metal elements are easy to precipitate together with the target metal, resulting in a decrease in the purity of the product. This is due to the similar chemical properties of transition metals Ni, Co, and Mn, which are prone to co-precipitation (Fig. 11b). Hence, leveraging this attribute of transition metals, direct regeneration of the cathode material precursor through co-precipitation can circumvent the need for intricate metal element separation, thereby curtailing production costs. 3.4.3 Electrodeposition Electrodeposition enables fast, simple, efficient, and selective recovery of metals from leach solutions in a highly controlled manner [170]. The standard reduction potential of the metal is crucial for selective electrodeposition [171]. Metals with higher standard reduction potentials can be more easily recovered by electrodeposition methods. Li (E 0 = −3.05 V vs. NHS) cannot simply be electrochemically deposited from the solution due to its strong negative potential. Therefore, Li element is usually recovered in the form of Li2CO3 using chemical precipitation after recovering other metals [172]. Since transition metals have similar standard reduction potentials, this can lead to the presence of impurities in the electrodeposited metal layer. Due to the large differences in the standard reduction potentials of Cu, Co, Fe, Mn, and Li, it is feasible to recover metal elements in LCO, LMO, and LFP cathodes individually or in their mixtures through electrodeposition [173]. However, significant challenges are encountered when using electrodeposition to recover pure metals from leach solutions containing NMC, NCA, or their mixtures. This primarily stems from the fact that cobalt (E 0 = −0.28 V vs. NHS) and nickel (E 0 = −0.26 V vs. NHS) possess similar standard reduction potentials, rendering them unsuitable for electrochemical recovery. Separating the two metals by solvent extraction before electrodeposition and then using electrodeposition to recover the pure metal is considered a viable approach. The efficiency and product purity of metals recovered by electrodeposition mainly depend on parameter conditions, such as current density, electrode materials, electrochemical methods, pH, etc. [174,170]. Precisely controlling the parameters of electrodeposition can significantly improve the yield and quality of recovered metals. 3.5 Direct regeneration Direct regeneration is a closed-loop recycling strategy that can help address the challenges associated with the disposal of spent LIBs. Direct regeneration of degraded cathode materials without destroying the atomic-level structure is a promising strategy [175,176]. Comprehending the failure or degradation mechanisms of electrode materials after charge–discharge cycles becomes imperative for the effective utilization of direct regeneration techniques. The degradation of LIBs predominantly hinges on the availability of Li+ and active materials [177,178]. In the initial few cycles, the active Li+ of the cathode is consumed along with the decomposition of the electrolyte, and passivation protective layers of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI) are formed on the surface of the anode and cathode, respectively [179,180]. The further development of this unstable passivation protective layer leads to the continuous loss of Li+. Lithium accumulates on the surface of the negative electrode in dendritic formations, and a portion of the expanding lithium dendrites undergoes conversion into irreversible lithium loss, colloquially termed as “dead lithium” (Fig. 12 ). The observed phenomena in spent cathodes are lithium loss, transition metal dissolution, and particle breakage, consequently resulting in compromised cycle performance and diminished reversible capacity. It has been reported that processes such as hydrothermal treatment, molten salt sintering, chemical/electrochemical lithiation, and solid-state sintering can effectively repair damaged spent cathode materials. Notably, solid-state sintering can significantly restore the electrochemical performance of the material by supplementing lithium and transition metal elements during high-temperature calcination [9]. The only valuable element in a degraded LFP battery is lithium, and current recycling methods have low economic value. Direct regeneration is an effective strategy to restore degraded LFP cathode materials to their original state. Lithium loss is the main reason for the formation of the Fe (III) phase in LFP, which leads to its capacity fading [181]. The formation of the Fe (III) phase causes defects in the LFP crystal structure. In a typical case, Cheng et al. used a multifunctional organic lithium salt (3,4-dihydroxybenzonitrile dilithium, Li2DHBN) to repair degraded LFP cathode materials through a direct regeneration process [182]. The organic salt is well combined with the degraded LFP particles through functional groups, allowing lithium ions to fill the vacancies (Fig. 13 a). During the solid-state sintering stage, the reducing atmosphere generated by the cyano groups in Li2DHBN reduces the formation of Fe (III). In particular, the amorphous carbon layer produced by the pyrolysis of organic salts covers the degraded LFP surface, improving the lithium-ion and electron transfer kinetics. The directly regenerated LFP exhibited good cycle stability and rate performance (88% capacity was maintained after 400 cycles at 5 C rate) (Fig. 13b). This organolithium salt was also shown to be useful in restoring highly degraded LCO and NCM523 materials. Solid-state sintering is the most widely used direct regeneration method, which involves mixing and calcining the degraded cathode material with lithium salts (mainly Li2CO3) at high temperatures to repair the crystal structure [183]. Previous direct regeneration has mainly focused on Li supplementation to the cathode material, while the loss of transition metal ions due to dissolution during long-term cycling has received less attention [184]. To meet these requirements, Zhang et al. designed a DES composed of LiCl and CH4N2O for the direct regeneration of LCO [185]. Remarkably, DES serves as a carrier for selectively replenishing Li and Co to repair degraded LCO (Fig. 13c). This process ensures the efficient supply of Li and Co in the degraded structure, leading to the restoration of the degraded LCO to satisfactory electrochemical performance. DES can be easily collected and reused many times, and this strategy has high environmental and economic benefits compared with traditional recycling methods. Directly converting degraded LCO into high-voltage LCO can improve electrochemical performance by increasing the cut-off voltage [186]. Li vacancies in degraded LCO can lower the diffusion energy barrier of doping elements Mg and Al, making it easier for Mg and Al to occupy Li sites. Furthermore, Mg and Al are more likely to diffuse uniformly in the degraded LCO, so the regenerated high-pressure LCO has a more stable structure. The regenerated LCO showed a high initial capacity (220.4 mA h g−1 at 0.1C) at a voltage of 4.6 V, and the capacity retention rate was 79.7% after 300 cycles. Converting spent LCO into high-performance high-pressure LCO can give waste materials new life and higher value [187]. However, insufficient CoO bonding in LCO will cause lattice distortion, release of lattice oxygen, dissolution of cobalt, and even structural collapse of high-pressure LCO during cycling [188]. A recent study demonstrated that using Ni/Mn collected from spent NCM523 as a dopant can enhance CoO bonding and adjust the coordination environment of atoms, thereby inhibiting the release of lattice oxygen at a high cut-off voltage of 4.6 V. Additionally, the doping of Ni/Mn will also suppress unfavorable phase transitions and parasitic side reactions between the cathode and the electrolyte [189]. Therefore, rational utilization of Ni/Mn atoms in spent NCM is expected to solve the lattice oxygen release of high-pressure LCO materials during the recycling process. The rock salt/spinel phase formed on the surface of spent NCM523 tends to hinder Li+ transport and the rapid decay of the regenerated material capacity [190]. Jia et al. [191] proposed a topological transformation strategy to achieve the phase transformation of the rock salt/spinel phase on the surface of spent NCM523 to Ni0.5Co0.2Mn0.3(OH)2 layered hydroxide by using ammonium hydroxide to pretreat NCM523 (Fig. 13d). This topological transformation is beneficial to the formation of improved Li+ transport channels and reduces the complexity of dynamics, thereby improving the Li+ transport efficiency in regenerated NCM523. Furthermore, this topology transformation method can be extended to repair spent LCO, NCM523, and NCM622 [191]. Lithium in anode graphite is often ignored due to its low concentration. Recently, Wang et al. [192] developed a direct regeneration strategy for comprehensive recovery of cathode and anode materials, a process that does not require the addition of external lithium salts. Specifically, lithium is recovered from lithiated graphite using an aqueous solution and then converted into Li2CO3. The recovered Li2CO3 is then employed for the direct regeneration of LCO and NCM523 materials. This innovative process can restore the capacity of LCO, even when it has deteriorated to various extents, to an impressive 130 mA h g−1. The performance of delithiated graphite can be restored to 370 mA h g−1 after purification. Notably, when recycled materials were used to assemble pouch cells, their cyclic performance was marginally superior to that of commercial pouch cells. This strategy establishes closed-circuit recycling of lithium inside spent LIBs and reduces production costs [192]. In spherical NCM materials, grain boundary cracking of secondary agglomerated particles can accelerate battery degradation during cycling. The single-crystal morphology limits surface reactions and reduces lattice expansion and crack formation, thereby extending the battery’s cycle life. Therefore, converting spherical NCM materials into single-crystal morphology avoids the risk of particle breakage during cycling. Dong et al. [193] proposed a strategy to regenerate spent NCM523 from secondary agglomerated particles into micron-single crystals. Single-crystal morphological layered cathode materials were successfully synthesized through mechanical activation and solid-state calcination. A LiAlO2 coating is formed on the surface of the material through hydrolysis and high-temperature annealing, achieving stable cycling and improved rate performance at a high voltage of 4.5 V [193]. This work overcomes the barrier between secondary particles and single crystals of cathode materials and provides a feasible solution for regenerating spent NCM into single crystal cathode materials. The spherical structure of NCM with high nickel content is prone to micro-cracks during cycling, and transition metal elements are also more likely to be dissolved. Therefore, converting spent high-nickel NCM into single crystal form can avoid the occurrence of micro-cracks in the grains during long cycles, and can also increase the cut-off voltage. In a typical case, Huang et al. [194] reported a recycling process that combines selective leaching with solid state calcination. The oxalic acid leaching process repairs the collapsed crystal structure of spent NCM622 and also removes impurity phases. Lithium lost in spent cathodes can be replenished by adding lithium oxalate to the suspension. The selective leaching of oxalic acid allows the hexahedral crystal skeleton of NCM622 to be retained. The initial discharge specific capacity of the regenerated single crystal NCM622 is 179.2 mA h g−1, and its capacity retention rate is 90.7% after 150 cycles at 0.2C, which is comparable to commercial NCM622 [194]. Upgrading and converting spent high-nickel NCM materials (such as NCM622/811) into single crystal materials is the development direction for the future industrial application of high-nickel materials. Mechanochemical activation helps to reduce the material particle size and shorten the ion diffusion distance and can improve the reversibility of Li-ion intercalation/deintercalation, alleviate cation mixing, and promote crystal structure reconstruction. Therefore, the method has great potential for application in the direct regeneration of spent LIBs. Meng et al. combined mechanochemical activation and solid-state calcination to directly regenerate NCM111 materials with well-structured crystals [196]. The Li lost in the cathode material is supplemented by the addition of lithium salt, and the residual organic matter such as PVDF is decomposed into a carbon source during the sintering process, which indirectly improves the conductivity of the material [197,198]. Another direct regeneration process involves hydrothermal methods, in which lithium salts and degraded cathodes are exposed to high temperature and pressure for several hours, followed by annealing to obtain repaired cathode materials. During the hydrothermal reaction, lithium ions are replenished to the vacancies, and the regenerated particles have original morphology and good electrochemical performance. Typically, the hydrothermal lithiation process necessitates elevated pressure conditions. Remarkably, Shi et al. [195] presented the first atmospheric pressure relithiation of a highly degraded NCM523 cathode by a eutectic lithium molten salt solution (Fig. 13e). This combined approach of a low-temperature relithiation process with a thermal annealing step successfully restores the composition and crystal structure of the pristine material. Additionally, the capacity, cycle stability, and rate performance of the spent LIBs were fully restored to their initial levels, and its specific discharge capacity at 5C reached 124.4 mA h g−1. The eutectic lithium salt system can provide a lithium-rich melting environment, which is conducive to ion diffusion. Eutectic salt systems have low melting points, helping to lower repair temperatures and shorten repair times. In particular, even the highly degraded NCM523 material was repaired in this molten salt environment. The lithium-rich liquid environment provided by the eutectic salt system is a good medium to solve the problem of lithium loss [199]. Conventional solid-phase sintering and hydrothermal remediation technologies are inefficient due to high energy consumption and long operating times. Recently, Yin et al. [200] achieved simultaneous relithiation and crystal structure repair of LCO cathode materials by flash Joule heating technique. Specifically, the flash Joule heat can repair the degraded LCO ultrafast in only 8 s at the optimal reaction temperature of 1440 K. The regenerated LCO has a clear layered structure, and its initial discharge-specific capacity reaches 133.0 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C. Furthermore, this technology also demonstrates unique advantages in the recovery of anode graphite. Specifically, only a few seconds of selective Joule heating is required to effectively decompose impurities [201] (Fig. 14 a−f). The anode recovered by flash Joule heat retains the graphitic structure, which has superior electrochemical performance compared with the anode material recovered by high-temperature calcination (Fig. 14g). This is attributed to the removal of impurities in the Joule heating stage, which enhances the degree of graphitization and interlayer spacing, making the recovered graphite more suitable for intercalation and deintercalation of lithium ions [202]. This technology has been proven to be able to recycle waste graphite materials on a large scale and has the advantage of significantly reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. Flash Joule heating technology opens up new avenues for ultrafast and efficient remediation of spent LIBs electrode materials. The direct regeneration process repairs spent cathode materials without destroying their crystal structure. Additionally, the process is short, low-cost, and environmentally friendly, so it has great potential. However, direct regeneration has strict requirements on the cathode materials to be repaired, and it is often difficult to repair cathodes with high impurity content and mixed types. Moreover, the severe cation mixing of transition metal oxides with high nickel content during cycling is also difficult to repair. Therefore, the direct regeneration process still faces severe challenges in the actual large-scale recycling of spent LIBs. 4 Regenerated functional materials The cathodes of spent batteries contain metals such as Li, Co, Ni, and Mn, which can be recovered and used to produce new batteries, electronic devices, and other metal products [203]. Plastic from recycled battery casings can be used to produce new plastic products such as auto parts, containers, and packaging. Purified electrolytes can be used in the production of new batteries or other chemical products such as fertilizers. The recycling of carbon can contribute to the fabrication of fresh carbon-oriented commodities like graphene, electrodes, and composites. 4.1 Regeneration of cathode material 4.1.1 Catalysts Transition metals such as Ni, Co, and Mn show excellent potential for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR)/oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [149,204]. Furthermore, layered lithium transition metal oxides (LiNi x Co y Mn1 − x − y O2) exhibit higher OER catalytic activity after the delithiation process [205–207]. Direct conversion of spent cathode materials into highly efficient catalysts can avoid complex element separation processes [208]. Recently, Jiao et al. [209] utilized acid leaching and rapid thermal radiation methods to convert spent NCM cathodes into efficient NiMnCo-AC catalysts for zinc-air batteries (ZABs) (Fig. 15 a). Interestingly, the NiMnCo-AC catalyst exhibits a unique core-shell structure with a core of face-centered cubic Ni and a shell of spinel-structured NiMnCoO4. Notably, the effective active sites on the Ni core and NiMnCoO4 shell cause a redistribution of the electronic structure, so that NiMnCo-AC has a low energy barrier in the ORR/OER process, which ensures high electrocatalytic activity. Zhang et al. [204] converted spent LFP into Ni-LFP through a wet impregnation method, which subsequently transformed into defect-rich NiFe oxygen/hydroxide nanosheets during an OER (Fig. 15b). This modified Ni-LFP exhibits a low overpotential of 285 mV and a small Tafel slope of 45 mV dec−1 at 10 mA cm−2. The results show that it outperforms pristine LFP and even the benchmark catalyst RuO2. The introduction of Ni optimizes the free energy of the *OOH intermediate and effectively activates the Fe sites, enhancing the OER performance of LFP. Water splitting through the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and OER polarization processes is considered the most efficient and greenest way to produce hydrogen [210]. In recent years, cobalt-based oxides and carbonaceous hybrids have been widely reported due to their advantages in electrocatalytic activity [211]. Therefore, recycling Co from spent LIBs and applying it to the field of catalysts can maximize the utilization of resources. For example, Liu et al. recovered cobalt from spent LIBs through a hydrometallurgical process and synthesized a three-dimensional (3D) sea urchin-like cobalt nitride composite [212]. The material has high electrical conductivity, a large specific surface area, and a unique 3D sea urchin-like structure. The catalyst exhibits low overpotentials of 128.9 and 280 mV for HER and OER, which are comparable to commercial 20 wt% Pt/C and RuO2 catalysts. Furthermore, when used for water splitting, it exhibits water splitting efficiency close to the Pt/C||RuO2 benchmark (1.6 V) [212]. The above work provides new opportunities for the large-scale preparation of multifunctional catalyst materials using spent LIBs cathode materials. 4.1.2 Sodium-ion batteries The reserves of Na element in the earth’s crust are far more abundant than Li, and they have similar electrochemical mechanisms, so sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are considered to be ideal substitutes for LIBs [213,214]. Carbon nanotubes, graphene, and 3D carbon have good sodium storage properties and are considered potential anode materials. Expanded graphite (EG) not only has oxygen-containing functional groups and defects but also has a larger interlayer spacing of graphene nanosheets, which can provide more active sites and ion transport channels [215]. In recent years, porous graphene (hG) has received great attention due to its unique nanostructure [216,217]. This is attributed to a large number of nanopores significantly reducing the p-p stacking and avoiding the agglomeration of graphene nanosheets during the redox process. Fortunately, lithiated graphite (LixC6) and delithiated Li1 − x FePO4 cathodes in spent batteries can serve as raw materials for porous graphene oxide (c-rhSG) and Na2FePO4F (NFPF), respectively [218]. Excitingly, NFPF and c-rhSG exhibited excellent sodium storage performance in both half-cell and full-cell tests. The regeneration of spent LIB into SIB enables comprehensive high-value utilization of electrode materials. 4.1.3 Supercapacitors Although there have been extensive works on the recovery of precious metals from spent LIBs, however, the preparation of nanostructured cobalt oxide (Co3O4) materials from spent LIBs has been rarely reported. Mao et al. [219] prepared Co3O4 hollow microspheres by simple solvothermal and calcination using spent LIBs metal leaching solution as a cobalt source. The results show that the synthesized Co3O4 hollow microspheres have a diameter of about 1 μm and a large number of mesopores, and the specific surface area of Co3O4 is about 60 m2 g−1. A large number of mesopores and high specific surface area are conducive to the preparation of high-performance supercapacitor electrode materials. The electrochemical performance tests of Co3O4 hollow microspheres show high specific capacitance and good cycle stability. This study demonstrates the feasibility of preparing Co3O4 nanomaterials from spent LIBs leachate, and the synthesized Co3O4 hollow microspheres can also serve as potential candidates for other applications, such as sensors and catalysis. 4.1.4 Adsorbent It has been reported that metal–organic frameworks can be obtained under hydrothermal conditions by adding organic ligands to the leaching solution, which increases the added value of recycling spent LIBs [220,221]. CoFe2O4 and Co3O4/LCO regenerated from the leachate were demonstrated to degrade organic dyes, and have excellent photocatalytic properties [222,223]. The cathode of the spent LCO/LFP battery can be used to catalyze the degradation of methylene blue and methyl orange. In particular, methylene blue can be completely decolorized in LCO cathodes by hydroxyl radicals [224]. There is also evidence that polymetallic nanoparticles prepared by reducing metal ions in the cathodic leachate of sodium borohydride have good decolourisation properties of organic dyes [225]. Xu et al. [226] extracted iron hydroxyphosphate complex (FPOH) from spent LFP cathode materials by hydrothermal treatment as an environmentally functional material. The prepared FPOH can adsorb heavy metals in water, and the maximum adsorption capacity of Pb (II) reaches 43.203 mg g−1. Moreover, FPOH also showed excellent Fenton-like catalytic performance, which could effectively degrade organic dyes within 12 h. This research introduces a novel dimension to spent LFP recycling, offering promising solutions to environmental pollution concerns. 4.2 High-value conversion of waste graphite Spent LIB anodes contain a considerable graphite content, ranging from 12% to 21% by weight, which is particularly valuable for nations with limited graphite reserves, such as the European Union and the United States [227,228]. Undoubtedly, waste graphite serves as an optimal resource for the synthesis of various functional materials, and the recycling of waste graphite is of great strategic significance. The subsequent discussion emphasizes pivotal literature concerning the generation of regenerated functional materials from waste graphite. 4.2.1 Graphenes During repeated charge–discharge processes, the interplanar spacing of anode graphite increases, which leads to the weakening of the van der Waals force between graphite layers [229,230]. The preparation of graphene requires breaking chemical bonds and separating the graphene layers, thus waste graphite can be considered to have undergone pretreatment. Oxygen-containing groups and structural defects in waste graphite make it easier to prepare graphene than natural graphite. Waster graphite and natural graphite were used as raw materials to prepare two types of graphene oxide by the Hummers method, and the results showed that the graphene oxide prepared from waste graphite exhibited better uniformity and electrochemical properties. Graphene is prepared by shear mixing, and lithiation-assisted pre-expansion can increase the production efficiency of graphene by four times. The acid treatment further expands the graphite lattice without breaking the sp2 bond and increases the graphene production efficiency to 83.7% (10 times higher than natural graphite) [229]. Schiavi et al. [231] successfully synthesized reduced graphene oxide (rGO) from spent LIBs by a modified Hummers method. This process simultaneously achieves the quantitative extraction of Ni, Co, and Mn and the synthesis of graphene oxide. In addition, the lithium-manganese-rich (Li1.2Mn0.55Ni0.15Co0.1O2, LMR) cathode material was directly synthesized using the manganese-rich metal solution obtained after filtration. The improved electrochemical performance of the recycled LMR compared to the material without any doping, coating was attributed to the doping of silicate, sulfate, and Cu2+ in the recycled material. This innovative integrated production method of graphene and cathode materials provides a promising route for the recycling of spent LIBs. 4.2.2 Supercapacitors Pseudocapacitive materials based on transition metal hydroxides/oxides (Co, Mn, Fe, and Ni) are widely used in supercapacitors due to their complex valence, high electrical conductivity, and faradaic activity [232]. Compared with single metal oxides, spinel structured MnCo2O4 (MCO) is more capable of transferring electrons/ions between cations, especially in terms of rate capability [233]. The transition metals present in spent LIBs (LMO + LCO) can be effectively regenerated from spent cathodes through acid leaching, and subsequently repurposed for energy storage devices beyond conventional batteries. The reutilization of waste graphite involves its conversion into rGO. Regenerated MCO and rGO can be used as electrode materials for the construction of asymmetric supercapacitors (ASCs) with positive and negative electrodes, respectively [234] (Fig. 16 a). The ASC assembled from spent LIBs achieved a maximum energy density of 23.9 W h kg−1 and excellent cycling stability for 8000 cycles with a capacitance retention rate of 94.4%. According to reports, Schiavi et al. [235] proposed a new recycling process that can directly use spent LIBs to produce ASCs. The cathode of a supercapacitor can be prepared directly from the electrolytic solutions of cathode powder by template nanowire electrodeposition. At the same time, recycled waste graphite can be used as the negative electrode of supercapacitors. The recycled nanowire-based cathode and graphite were assembled into an ASC whose electrochemical performance was close to the optimal values of supercapacitors based on cobalt–nickel and graphene. The proposal of this recovery process eliminates the expensive and complex metal element separation steps in traditional hydrometallurgical and pyrometallurgical processes, such as solvent extraction and elemental precipitation. All of the above recycling processes offer the possibility of comprehensively utilizing spent LIBs electrode materials to build high-energy storage devices. 4.2.3 Composite phase-change materials Multifunctional composite phase change materials (CPCMs) with dual photo/electrothermal trigger functions have great potential in the field of sustainable energy [236]. Photo/electrically triggered CPCM is composed of graphene, carbon nanotubes, and phase change materials. However, the practical application of these materials is often limited by the complexity and high cost of preparation methods.
