The use of cheap graphite from spent anodes as a raw material for the preparation of graphite foam (GF) can solve the cost problem of producing CPCM (Fig. 16b). Due to the high thermal/electrical conductivity and excellent solar light absorption capacity of GF, paraffin wax (PW) was doped into GF as a phase change material (PCM), and the synthesized GF-PW CPCM also had excellent light/electrothermal conversion capabilities. GF-PW CPCM prepared from waste graphite exhibited high latent enthalpy (173.9 to 209.2 J g−1), thermal stability, and cycle performance [237]. Employing waste graphite as the raw constituent for CPCMs presents a straightforward, cost-effective methodology, underscoring the potential of CPCMs in driving advancements within photo/electrothermal energy storage and conversion applications. 4.2.4 Catalysts and adsorbents Waste graphite has a large specific surface area and is doped with a small number of metallic impurities, which results in a higher degree of defects and favors catalytic activity and mass transfer efficiency. Highly active and environmentally friendly carbonaceous catalysts are widely used in advanced oxidation processes (AOPs). Recovering waste graphite from acid leaching residues and modifying it for catalytic ozonation of oxalic acid (OA) can achieve its high-value utilization. The impurity components demonstrated a large promotion at lower temperatures, which could remove 95% of OA by catalytic ozonation within 1 h. It was observed that the modified graphite exhibited outstanding performance in simulating the catalytic ozonation of the insoluble pollutant oxalic acid [238]. Impressively, pyridinic N and surface defects are the main active sites for catalysis, while the catalysts with defects as the dominant active sites exhibit more stable catalytic activity. This work presents a practical method for the recycling of acid leaching residues/graphite, and the modified graphite shows great potential for catalysis. Additionally, Zhao et al. [239] grafted MnO2 particles onto waste graphite to prepare a novel adsorbent that can be used to treat water polluted by Pb (II), Cd (II), and Ag (I). The surface of the prepared adsorbent (MnO2-AG) is coated with MnO2 ultrafine particles, which can adsorb heavy metal ions. Compared with natural graphite, MnO2-AG exhibited stronger adsorption capacity. Specifically, its removal efficiencies for Pb (II), Cd (II), and Ag (I) were as high as 99.9%, 79.7%, and 99.8%, respectively. This excellent adsorption capacity was attributed to the ion exchange mechanism of the hydroxyl group. This study thus underscores the potential of leveraging waste graphite for the synthesis of environmentally friendly, cost-effective, and efficient adsorbents. 5 Environmental impacts and economic feasibility The production, disposal, and recycling of LIBs can have a profound impact on the environment [31]. Employing life cycle assessment (LCA) aids in comprehensively evaluating potential environmental implications throughout diverse phases of the battery recycling process, providing governments and industries with informed decision-making insights [21] The LCA for batteries encompasses the extraction of raw materials, manufacturing, battery use stages, recycling, disposal, etc. To determine the primary environmental impact contributor within the recycling process, researchers conducted the LCA of LIBs [240]. The study found that raw material extraction and battery utilization phases exerted the most significant environmental influence, while recycling mitigated the environmental footprint. Therefore, recycling spent LIBs offers several environmental advantages. For instance, recycling prevents batteries from ending up in landfills or being incinerated. Moreover, recycling diminishes the necessity for precious metal mining and curbs greenhouse gas emissions. Pollution stemming from battery components, including heavy metals, is mitigated through proper handling and processing during recycling. Incorporating recycled materials into battery production curtails the requirement for energy-intensive extraction and refining operations, thereby reducing emissions. Economic considerations hold paramount significance in the recycling of spent LIBs, as they dictate the industrial feasibility of recycling technologies. The economic viability of battery recycling depends on a variety of factors, including the type and quantity of batteries, the market value of recycled materials, and the costs associated with collection, transportation, and processing. The market value of recycled materials can fluctuate based on prevailing supply and demand dynamics. For instance, the price of Li, Co, and Ni can exhibit variability tied to global market conditions. However, as demand for these materials increases with the growth of electric vehicles and renewable energy storage, the market value of recycled materials is likely to rise as well. Using recycled materials can also offer cost savings, as it reduces the need for virgin materials and associated extraction and processing costs. In addition, using recycled materials can reduce the need for waste disposal and associated costs. However, there are several challenges to recycling spent LIBs, such as collection and transportation logistics. The retrieval of spent LIBs, especially from remote or rural regions, can be intricate. Moreover, transportation costs can be substantial. Notably, handling and processing spent LIBs require specialized equipment and expertise to ensure worker safety and prevent environmental damage. There may be some specially designed batteries that are difficult to recycle, especially those with integrated electronic components or complex chemistries. Varied national regulations concerning battery recycling further complicate the establishment of standardized and cost-effective recycling methodologies. Future pathways for battery recycling include developing more efficient and cost-effective recycling techniques, improving battery design for easier recycling, and establishing global regulatory frameworks for battery recycling (Fig. 17 ). Despite the encountered challenges, the potential economic and environmental gains render the pursuit of recycling spent LIBs a commendable endeavor. 6 Conclusions Spent LIBs contain a range of valuable metals, and their recycling offers a solution to resource scarcity and environmental contamination. This review provides a comprehensive overview of the need to recycle spent LIBs, including recent advances in pyrometallurgy, hydrometallurgy, biometallurgy, direct regeneration, and regeneration of electrode materials into functional materials. Certain pretreatment processes can change the valence of metals, which is beneficial to the subsequent leaching and separation of electrode materials. Pyrometallurgy can process spent LIBs on a large scale. However, the purity of the recovered metal needs to be further improved. Biometallurgy is still at the scale of laboratory research due to shortcomings such as long microbial culture cycles and high economic costs. Hydrometallurgy has become the most widely spent LIBs recycling process due to its high recycling efficiency and low energy consumption. Although inorganic acids have significant advantages in terms of acidity and metal leaching rates, they produce large amounts of waste acid. In contrast, organic acids combine acidity, chelating properties, and environmental friendliness, giving them unique advantages in the leaching process. Some organic acids also have reducing properties and can convert insoluble high-valent transition metal oxides into easily soluble low-valent metals. DES can recover metal elements from spent LIBs, with a leaching effect even after multiple uses. This environmentally friendly, low-toxic, and easy-to-synthesize DES solvent brings hope to the field of battery recycling. Compared with hydrometallurgy, direct regeneration can effectively repair degraded cathode materials and restore their electrochemical performance. However, highly degraded nickel-rich NCM (such as NCM811) materials have severe cation mixing, making their direct regeneration difficult. Therefore, new technologies for direct regeneration of high-nickel materials should be developed. It is very attractive to directly regenerate polycrystalline electrode materials into single-crystal materials by taking advantage of the property of grain cracking during cycling. In recent years, the cathode formula of NCM materials has been updated rapidly, and corresponding direct regeneration processes should be developed for different cathode materials. Directly upgrading the low-value anode graphite in spent LIBs into carbon-based functional materials such as graphene can significantly increase its added value. In addition, attention should also be paid to the recycling of materials such as current collectors, electrolytes, and separators to produce high-value-added products. Additionally, the next generation of batteries may use solid electrolytes. For this reason, it is still necessary to continue to research advanced spent LIBs reuse and recycling technologies to solve the increasingly serious problems of environmental pollution and resource shortages. 7 Challenges and prospects Recycling spent LIBs presents several challenges, encompassing safety concerns, collection and sorting complexities, technical limitations, and economic viability. The presence of hazardous chemicals and materials in many batteries necessitates caution to safeguard workers and the environment during the recycling process. Moreover, the diverse types, sizes, and chemistries of batteries pose challenges in collecting and sorting them from various sources. The intricate process of dismantling and segregating the multifaceted components of batteries demands specialized equipment and expertise, rendering it a complex undertaking. The economic feasibility of battery recycling faces hurdles due to the high recycling costs and the relatively low value of the recovered materials. Viable strategies to address these challenges primarily involve standardization heightened public awareness, and technological advancements. The development of standardized batteries and recycling methods holds promise for streamlining procedures and mitigating costs. Educating the public about proper battery disposal and recycling can bolster collection rates and reduce contamination risks. Developing new and improved technologies for battery recycling can increase efficiency and reduce the cost of the process. This review provides an assessment of recent technological advancements in battery recycling and presents some perspectives. (1) Battery classification and testing. Given the varying shapes, sizes, and chemical compositions of spent LIBs, establishing standardized protocols for recycling battery components poses challenges. Implementing uniform labeling by battery manufacturers could simplify the sorting and disassembly of batteries with similar chemical compositions. Alternatively, automated battery disassembly processes might mitigate safety concerns. The use of non-destructive testing and analytical methods can provide advanced insights into the battery’s condition, thereby enhancing the accuracy of classification. (2) Short process metallurgy. The traditional metallurgical process easily produces a large amount of waste residue and harmful substances, and causes serious pollution to the environment. Short-process metallurgy is more environmentally friendly and can reduce the generation of waste and the emission of harmful substances. Short-process metallurgical can more efficiently separate and extract valuable materials from spent LIBs. Additionally, short-process metallurgy is generally more efficient and can shorten battery recycling cycles. The development of short-process metallurgical processes is critical for large-scale recycling of spent LIBs. (3) Development of low-cost lithium supplements. Some lithium supplements (organolithium salts) are expensive and are often uneconomical in repairing lower value electrode materials. Moreover, challenges persist in the direct regeneration of high-nickel layered transition metal oxide materials (e.g., NCM811), such as pronounced Li/Ni mixing, structural deformation, and related issues. Developing economical lithium supplements and solving the capacity degradation problem of high-nickel materials will move the direct regeneration process toward practical applications. (4) Utilizing spent LIBs to manufacture functional materials such as catalysts, adsorbents, and supercapacitors can reduce reliance on limited resources. However, impurity elements contained in spent LIBs materials may affect the performance of regenerated adsorbents, such as adsorption capacity and selectivity. Additionally, the production of supercapacitors requires materials with high conductivity and capacitive properties, and some spent LIBs may not meet these requirements. To overcome these challenges, materials need to be purified, impurity content strictly controlled, and the preparation process and material design of functional materials improved. By improving electrode materials through various means, it is expected to realize the widespread application of spent LIBs materials in the field of functional materials. (5) Rational battery design. The rational design of LIBs, encompassing the assembly of battery components and the selection and modification of electrode materials, profoundly influences recycling. The use of water-based adhesive will facilitate the stripping of the current collector, and the detachable packaging technology will facilitate the recovery of electrode powder. Notably, widely-used hydrometallurgy involves the destruction of the crystal structure of the material, and the transformation of metal elements into ions in solution, leading to substantial chemical consumption and environmental concerns. Therefore, designing next-generation energy storage batteries should aim to circumvent issues encountered in the LIB recycling process. The battery design should prioritize recyclability rather than merely striving for high-energy–density energy storage devices. (6) Comprehensive legislation and regulations by government. The government should formulate new policies with the development of recycling technology and market size. Public education initiatives should inform users about battery hazards and the economic and environmental implications of recycling used batteries. Besides, providing subsidies to the recycling industry, especially for low-value-added batteries, would incentivize public engagement and awareness. (7) Data-driven battery recycling. In the era of rapid advancements in artificial intelligence, big data, and the Internet of Things, the recycling of spent LIBs is undergoing a digital transformation. Integrating cloud data, artificial intelligence, and smart battery management systems (BMS) allows precise monitoring of battery life cycles, thereby optimizing battery management efficiency. When the battery is decommissioned, it can be evaluated directly based on the detection data, and then the battery can be directly sent to the corresponding application scenario. Pengwei Li received his B.S. and MSc degrees in Materials Science and Engineering from Northeastern University in 2017 and 2019, respectively. He is carrying out his Ph.D. research at Northeastern University under the supervision of Prof. Shaohua Luo. Currently, his research focuses on the recycling of spent lithium-ion batteries. Shaohua Luo received his MSc degree and Ph.D. degree in materials science and engineering from Tsinghua University in 2003 and 2007, respectively. He joined Northeastern University in 2007 and became a professor in 2015. Currently, he is a full professor at Northeastern University and the dean of the School of Resources and Materials, Northeastern University at Qinhuangdao. His research interests include recycling spent Li-ion batteries, energy storage materials, and ceramic materials. He has published more than 100 papers in peer-reviewed journals as the first author and corresponding author. Additionally, he has successfully hosted the National Natural Science Foundation. Lin Zhang received her B.S. and MSc degrees in Materials Science and Engineering from University of Science and Technology Liaoning in 2017 and 2020, respectively. She is carrying out his Ph.D. research at Northeastern University under the supervision of Prof. Shaohua Luo. Currently, her research focuses on lithium-oxygen batteries. Qiuyue Liu received her B.S. degree in Mechanical Design Manufacturing and Automation from Xinyu University in 2022. She is currently pursuing her master’s degree at Northeastern University under the supervision of Prof. Shaohua Luo, with Associate Professor Fei Teng as her co-advisor. Her current research focuses on the synthesis and characterization of novel electrode materials for lithium/sodium-ion batteries. Yikai Wang received his B.S. degree in materials science and Engineering from Hebei University of Science and Technology in 2021. He is engaged in master’s research at Northeastern University under Prof. Shaohua Luo. At present, his research focuses on the recycling of spent LiFePO4 batteries. Yicheng Lin received his B.S. and MSc degrees in Materials Science and Engineering from Jiangxi University of Science and Technology in 2017 and 2020, respectively. He is carrying out his Ph.D. research at Northeastern University under the supervision of Prof. Shaohua Luo. Currently, his research focuses on the electrodes of secondary ion batteries, as well as electrolytes. Can Xu received her B.S. in Inorganic Non-metallic Materials Engineering from Henan University of Science and Technology in 2016 and received her MSc degree in Materials Engineering from Ningbo University in 2019. She is carrying out her Ph.D. research at Northeastern University under the supervision of Prof. Xianwei Hu. Currently, her research focuses on determining the morphology of molten salt by Raman spectroscopy and quantum mechanical calculation. Jia Guo is currently pursuing a Ph.D. in the Energy Department at Aalborg University in Denmark, where he began his doctoral studies in 2021. He completed his master’s degree at the School of Metallurgy and Environment, Central South University in China, in 2020. His academic and research interests primarily revolve around battery aging mechanisms, electrochemical analysis, operando testing of electrode materials, and cathode preparation. He also is the ECS and ISE student member. Peam Cheali received his B.S. and MSc degrees in Chemical Engineering from King Mongkut’s University North Bangkok, Thailand with cooperation with RWTH Aachen, in 2007, 2009, and Ph.D. degree in Chemical and Biochemical Engineering at Technical University of Denmark in 2015. Currently, his research works focus on the circularity of materials, i.e., Phosphorus recovery for circular economy. Xiaoning Xia received her B.S. degree from the School of Economics and Business Administration of Chongqing University in 2017. She is carrying out her Ph.D. research at Chongqing University under the supervision of Prof. Rong Zhang. Currently, she focuses on the economic and environmental impacts of batteries and electric vehicles.

coredata.dc:description: The recycling and reutilization of spent lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have become an important measure to alleviate problems like resource scarcity and environmental pollution. Although some progress has been made, battery recycling technology still faces challenges in terms of efficiency, effectiveness and environmental sustainability. This review aims to systematically review and analyze the current status of spent LIB recycling, and conduct a detailed comparison and evaluation of different recycling processes. In addition, this review introduces emerging recycling techniques, including deep eutectic solvents, molten salt roasting, and direct regeneration, with the intent of enhancing recycling efficiency and diminishing environmental repercussions. Furthermore, to increase the added value of recycled materials, this review proposes the concept of upgrading recycled materials into high value-added functional materials, such as catalysts, adsorbents, and graphene. Through life cycle assessment, the paper also explores the economic and environmental impacts of current battery recycling and highlights the importance that future recycling technologies should achieve a balance between recycling efficiency, economics and environmental benefits. Finally, this review outlines the opportunities and challenges of recycling key materials for next-generation batteries, and proposes relevant policy recommendations to promote the green and sustainable development of batteries, circular economy, and ecological civilization.
